keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up'.
Cagle was not armed at the time of arrest, but police found an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle parked outside.

He faces multiple charges including terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assaults, possession of a firearm in commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a convicted felon.
Cagle has a prior conviction for marijuana possession over two decades ago, and authorities note he is mentally challenged.
The FBI is assisting in the investigation, and Atlanta Police Chief Darin Schierbaum described the incident as a 'tragedy averted'.
The man was already at the airport before being intercepted, having arrived at the south terminal shortly before 9:30 a.m. and showing interest in the TSA check-in area.
Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport is the busiest airport in the world and the busiest in the United States, with over 108 million passengers in 2024.
The incident underscores the importance of community vigilance, as Cagle’s family's early warning helped prevent a potential mass incident.
Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem publicly expressed gratitude that the individual was taken into custody before any harm occurred.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Billy Joe Cagle, who lives in Cartersville, Georgia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up'. Although not armed at the time of arrest, police discovered an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle. Cagle faces multiple charges, including terroristic threats, aggravated assault, and possession of a firearm by a convicted felon. Authorities note he has a prior marijuana conviction and is mentally challenged. The incident occurred shortly before 9:30 a.m. when Cagle arrived at the airport’s south terminal and showed interest in the TSA check-in area. The airport, the world’s busiest, is a critical hub, and the event underscores the importance of community vigilance and coordinated law enforcement response. The FBI is assisting in the investigation, and officials including Atlanta Police Chief Darin Schierbaum and Mayor Andre Dickens emphasized that the incident was a 'tragedy averted'. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem praised the law enforcement action as a success in preventing potential mass harm.
title: Man Arrested Inside Atlanta Airport After Making Threats to ‘Shoot It Up’
